patterns.description: A high-level summary component that displays key account metrics such as Total Equity, Available Balance, and Unrealized PnL. It is highly configurable via the `elementKeys` prop.
patterns.usage: Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-scaffold. Use this in the header of your app or the top of the dashboard to give users a quick overview of their account health.
notes: The `elementKeys` prop allows you to strictly control which data points are shown.
Data is automatically fetched from the Orderly context.
Supports custom rendering if you need to wrap values in specific styles.

patterns.name: BottomNav
patterns.description: A mobile-first bottom navigation bar component used to switch between primary views in the application.
patterns.usage: Use this component to render the primary navigation menu on mobile devices. It accepts an array of menu items and handles the active state highlighting.
notes: Ensure your menu items include both an 'icon' and an 'activeIcon' for visual feedback.
Typically used within a MobileScaffold or fixed at the bottom of the viewport.

patterns.name: BottomNavWidget
patterns.description: A widget wrapper for the BottomNav that likely encapsulates state management and routing logic for the navigation bar.
patterns.usage: Use this when you want a drop-in navigation solution that handles its own state and menu configuration without manually passing props.
notes: This is useful for quick scaffolding where custom menu configuration isn't immediately necessary.
It automatically integrates with the app's routing context.

patterns.name: BottomNavTradingMenu
patterns.description: A specific menu item component designed for the trading context within the bottom navigation.
patterns.usage: Use this to render individual tabs, specifically for trading-related sections, within a custom navigation container.
notes: Requires 'active' prop to toggle between the standard icon and 'activeIcon'.
Often used inside the 'mainMenus' array definition for the BottomNav.

patterns.name: FooterWidget
patterns.description: A footer component typically used to display version information, legal links, or network status.
patterns.usage: Place this at the bottom of your application layout, often outside the main scrollable area or within a desktop scaffold.
notes: Useful for displaying static information like Terms of Service or App Version.
Can be hidden on mobile if screen real estate is limited.

patterns.name: CloseIcon
patterns.description: A reusable close (X) icon component used for dismissing modals, alerts, or clearing inputs.
patterns.usage: Implement this anywhere a user needs to close a UI element. It supports custom sizing and opacity.
notes: Commonly used with 'size' prop 16 or 20.
Accepts standard className props for styling hover states.

patterns.name: MainNavWidget
patterns.description: The main navigation widget, typically displayed as a sidebar or top bar on desktop/tablet views.
patterns.usage: Use this to provide the primary navigation structure for non-mobile layouts.
notes: Contrasts with BottomNav which is mobile-specific.
May contain links to Trade, Portfolio, and Wallet sections.

patterns.name: OfflineInfoWidget
patterns.description: A widget component designed to alert users when the application is offline or experiencing connectivity issues.
patterns.usage: Render this conditionally when network status changes to inform the user they cannot interact with the blockchain.
notes: Should be positioned prominently (e.g., top of screen) so it is immediately visible.
Often integrates with window 'online' and 'offline' event listeners.

patterns.name: MobileScaffold
patterns.description: A layout wrapper component specifically designed for mobile views, handling headers, footers, and content areas.
patterns.usage: Wrap your mobile page content with this to ensure consistent spacing, header positioning, and footer integration.
notes: Accepts 'header' and 'footer' props to inject navigation bars.
Ensures the content area takes up the remaining height correctly.

patterns.name: DesktopScaffold
patterns.description: A specialized layout component specifically designed for desktop viewports. It provides a structure optimized for larger screens, often used in conjunction with responsive logic to switch between mobile and desktop layouts.
patterns.usage: Implement this inside a conditional render or a separate route for desktop-only views to ensure optimal use of screen real estate.
notes: Best used when you want to enforce a desktop-specific layout structure.
Often used alongside responsive breakpoints to hide/show on different devices.

patterns.name: Scaffold
patterns.description: The main layout wrapper component that renders the application structure, including the header, sidebar area, and footer. It handles the responsive layout structure for the web app.
patterns.usage: Use this to wrap your page content. It automatically integrates with the ScaffoldProvider to handle layout state.
notes: Ensure ScaffoldProvider is a parent of this component.
footerProps allows customization of social links and footer content.

patterns.name: ScaffoldProvider
patterns.description: A context provider that manages the global state for the Scaffold layout, such as sidebar expansion and routing integration. It is required to be placed at the root of your application when using Scaffold components.
patterns.usage: Wrap your entire application or the specific section using the Scaffold layout with this provider to enable state management for navigation and layout components.
notes: Required parent component for Scaffold and SideNavbarWidget.
routerAdapter is optional but useful for integrating with Next.js or React Router.

patterns.name: SideNavbarWidget
patterns.description: A sidebar navigation widget that renders a list of menu items. It integrates with the Scaffold layout to provide collapsible navigation links.
patterns.usage: Place this within the sidebar slot of your Scaffold layout or use it as a standalone navigation component if building a custom layout.
notes: Items typically require an icon, label, and path.
Interacts with ScaffoldProvider state for expansion/collapse.

patterns.name: SubAccountUI
patterns.description: A UI component for displaying and managing sub-accounts. It typically renders a dropdown or modal allowing users to switch between different trading sub-accounts.
patterns.usage: Place in the header or settings area to allow users to context-switch between their sub-accounts.
notes: Accepts a customTrigger prop to override the default button appearance.
Requires sub-account state context to function correctly.

patterns.name: Dot
patterns.description: A small indicator component used for carousels or sliders. It visually represents the active index among a list of items.
patterns.usage: Map over an array of items and render a Dot for each, passing the active state based on the current selection index.
notes: Commonly used in Share PnL carousels or image galleries.
Styling changes based on the 'active' prop.

patterns.name: PriceInput
patterns.description: A specialized input field for entering order prices. It handles formatting, validation, and often displays market context like Best Bid/Offer (BBO) to assist the user.
patterns.usage: Use in trading forms where users need to input a specific price for Limit, Stop, or Take-Profit orders.
notes: Requires 'bbo' (Best Bid/Offer) data to highlight market prices.
Behavior changes based on 'order_type' (e.g., Market vs Limit).

patterns.name: TPSL
patterns.description: A Take-Profit / Stop-Loss configuration component. It provides a UI for users to set trigger prices and execution prices to manage risk on open positions.
patterns.usage: Render inside a position details modal or a dedicated trading panel to allow users to configure automated exit points for their trades.
notes: Handles the logic for both Long and Short positions.
Requires callbacks for onCancel and onComplete to handle form submission.

patterns.name: TPSLWidget
patterns.description: A widget component used to manage Take Profit (TP) and Stop Loss (SL) orders for a specific trading position. It provides inputs for setting trigger prices and order sizes.
patterns.usage: Use this component in position management panels or trading modals to allow users to define risk management parameters for open positions.
notes: Requires position context (symbol, type, quantity) to calculate valid price ranges.
Usually integrated into a larger position details view.

patterns.name: TPSLSimpleDialogUI
patterns.description: The 'dumb' UI component for the TPSL dialog. It renders the form fields and layout but relies on external state for values and event handlers.
patterns.usage: Use this when you need full control over the state management of the TP/SL form, or when building a custom wrapper around the standard UI.
notes: This component does not handle API calls or validation logic internally.
Props are spread directly into the component, so state must be managed by the parent.

patterns.name: TPSLSimpleDialogWidget
patterns.description: A 'smart' widget version of the TPSL dialog. It encapsulates the UI, state management, and logic for submitting TP/SL orders.
patterns.usage: Ideal for quick integration where you need a ready-to-use modal for setting Take Profit and Stop Loss without building the form logic yourself.
notes: Handles internal validation and submission logic.
Requires symbol and position context to function correctly.

patterns.name: DesktopDisplayControl
patterns.description: A control bar component designed for desktop views to toggle various TradingView display options like indicators, drawings, and settings.
patterns.usage: Place this in the header or toolbar of a desktop chart layout to give users control over the chart's visual elements.
notes: Typically positioned in the top-right corner of the chart container.
Styling is optimized for mouse interaction (hover states).

patterns.name: MobileDisplayControl
patterns.description: A mobile-optimized control component for TradingView. It usually presents options in a touch-friendly layout, often as a dropdown or a compact icon row.
patterns.usage: Use in mobile chart views to save screen real estate while providing access to essential chart settings.
notes: Layout adapts to smaller screens.
Often triggers bottom sheets or menus on tap.

patterns.name: TimeInterval
patterns.description: A selector component for changing the chart's time resolution (timeframe). It displays the current interval and allows switching between predefined options.
patterns.usage: Essential for any chart interface, allowing users to switch between 1m, 5m, 1h, etc.
notes: Usually renders as a row of buttons or a segmented control.
The 'value' prop should match the TradingView library's expected resolution string.

patterns.name: MobileTimeInterval
patterns.description: A mobile-specific version of the TimeInterval selector, often featuring horizontal scrolling or a dropdown to accommodate limited screen width.
patterns.usage: Implement in mobile trading views to allow timeframe switching without cluttering the UI.
notes: Supports horizontal swiping for interval selection.
Touch targets are larger for better usability.

patterns.name: ZoomOutIcon
patterns.description: An SVG icon component representing a 'Zoom Out' action. It is typically used within chart toolbars to decrease the chart scale.
patterns.usage: Use in custom chart toolbars or display controls where you need a manual zoom out button.
notes: Accepts standard className props for styling.
Often paired with a ZoomInIcon.

patterns.name: ZoomInIcon
patterns.description: A simple SVG icon component designed for TradingView interfaces, typically used to trigger a zoom-in action on a chart.
patterns.usage: Use this in chart toolbars or control panels where users need to increase the scale of the visual data.
notes: Supports standard HTML attributes like className and onClick.
Uses Orderly's specific utility classes (e.g., oui-text-base-contrast-54) for theming.

patterns.name: LtvUI
patterns.description: A presentational component that displays the Loan-to-Value (LTV) ratio. It focuses on visual rendering rather than complex state management.
patterns.usage: Ideal for dashboards or summary cards where you need to display the user's current borrowing ratio without interaction.
notes: Props are inferred based on standard LTV components (value, max).
Typically used to show a static snapshot of account health.

patterns.name: LtvWidget
patterns.description: An interactive widget that calculates and displays the Loan-to-Value ratio, often showing the difference (diff) between the current LTV and the projected LTV based on user input.
patterns.usage: Essential in transfer or borrowing modals to show users how their LTV will change if they add or remove collateral.
notes: The showDiff prop controls whether the projected change is displayed.
Requires quantity or similar input props to perform calculations.

patterns.name: AccountSelect
patterns.description: A dropdown component allowing users to select between different accounts (e.g., Main Account vs. Sub Accounts) for transfers or trading.
patterns.usage: Use in transfer forms or settings where funds need to be moved between different internal accounts.
notes: Requires an array of account objects passed to subAccounts.
Controlled component: value and onValueChange must be managed.

patterns.name: ActionButton
patterns.description: A versatile button component that handles various states (loading, success, error) and specific actions like signing in or enabling trading.
patterns.usage: The primary call-to-action button in forms, modals, and trading interfaces.
notes: The state prop dictates the visual loading state.
actionType determines the button text and default behavior.

patterns.name: ChainSelect
patterns.description: A dropdown selector for choosing the blockchain network (chain) for deposits, withdrawals, or transfers.
patterns.usage: Critical in cross-chain transfer flows to ensure the user selects the correct source or destination network.
notes: Expects an array of chain objects containing metadata like chainId and name.
Controlled component requiring value and onValueChange.

patterns.name: CollateralContribution
patterns.description: A component that displays the amount of collateral being contributed, handling specific precision requirements (typically for stablecoins like USDC).
patterns.usage: Used in margin trading or lending interfaces to show exactly how much value is being added to a position.
notes: Precision is important here; USDC usually uses 6 decimals.
Formats the value for display purposes.

patterns.name: CollateralRatioUI
patterns.description: A presentational component displaying the collateral ratio (Health Factor), indicating the safety of a user's position against liquidation.
patterns.usage: Display in portfolio summaries or position details to give users a quick visual check on their risk level.
notes: Props are inferred (value) as no internal usage was provided.
Often color-coded (Green for safe, Red for danger).

patterns.name: CollateralRatioWidget
patterns.description: A visual widget that displays the user's current collateral ratio. It typically uses color coding (e.g., green for safe, red for liquidation risk) to indicate the health of the margin account based on the provided value.
patterns.usage: Use this in portfolio or margin account overview sections to give users a quick visual check on their account health.
notes: The component handles the visual representation (color/progress) based on the numerical value passed.
Ensure the value passed is a number representing the ratio (e.g., 1.5 for 150%).

patterns.name: ConvertAction
patterns.description: A button component designed specifically for executing token conversions. It manages loading states and disabled states while interacting with the specific network logic.
patterns.usage: Place this at the bottom of a conversion form. It triggers the actual swap or cross-chain transfer logic.
notes: Requires a networkId to ensure the transaction is broadcast to the correct chain.
The 'loading' prop should be controlled by the parent component during async operations.

patterns.name: ConvertFormUI
patterns.description: A presentational component (UI) that renders the input fields for a conversion form. It does not contain logic for fetching rates or executing trades but handles the layout and user input for 'From' and 'To' fields.
patterns.usage: Use this when you need a custom layout for the conversion inputs but want to rely on Orderly's styling and input handling logic.
notes: This is a 'dumb' component. You must manage the state (amount, selected tokens) in the parent component.
Requires token metadata objects to display symbols and logos correctly.

patterns.name: ConvertFormWidget
patterns.description: A fully functional 'smart' component that encapsulates the entire conversion flow. It likely includes the ConvertFormUI, fetches exchange rates, manages balances, and integrates with the ConvertAction.
patterns.usage: The quickest way to add conversion functionality to your app without building the form logic yourself.
notes: Wraps the logic and UI into a single drop-in component.
May require specific context providers (like WalletProvider) to function correctly.

patterns.name: DepositStatus
patterns.description: A visual indicator component that shows the current state of a deposit transaction (e.g., Pending, Success, Failed). It provides feedback to the user after they initiate a transfer.
patterns.usage: Display this immediately after a user triggers a deposit to keep them informed about the transaction progress.
notes: Props usually include status enums, transaction hash for block explorer links, and amount details.
Useful for inline feedback or modal confirmations.

patterns.name: DepositStatusWidget
patterns.description: A more advanced version of DepositStatus that includes interactive elements, such as a button to navigate to the portfolio or view transaction details. It aggregates status information with user actions.
patterns.usage: Ideal for a dashboard or dedicated transfer page where the user needs to take the next step after a deposit.
notes: Includes an onClick handler to facilitate navigation to detailed views.
Often used in conjunction with a broader transfer flow.

patterns.name: MinimumReceived
patterns.description: A small informational component that displays the minimum amount of tokens a user will receive after a conversion, accounting for price impact and slippage.
patterns.usage: Place this near the 'Convert' or 'Swap' button to ensure transparency regarding transaction output.
notes: Requires the target token's precision to format the number correctly.
Helps comply with DeFi best practices for displaying slippage.

patterns.name: DepositProvider
patterns.description: A React Context Provider that supplies deposit-related state and logic (like transaction history, current deposit status, and token allowances) to its child components.
patterns.usage: Wrap your application or specific transfer routes with this provider to enable data fetching and state management for deposit components.
notes: Must be placed higher in the component tree than any components consuming the context.
Essential for the internal workings of Widgets like DepositStatusWidget.

patterns.name: TokenOption
patterns.description: A selectable component that displays token information (icon, symbol) and handles balance fetching. It is typically used within dropdowns or lists for selecting source/destination tokens.
patterns.usage: npm install @orderly.network/ui-transfer
notes: The `displayType` prop controls whether the component shows a full list item or a compact icon view.
The `fetchBalance` prop is an async function used to update the displayed balance when the component mounts or refreshes.
Ensure the `token` object follows the standard Orderly token structure (symbol, address, decimals).

patterns.name: SwapDepositProvider
patterns.description: A Context Provider that manages the global state for swapping and depositing tokens. It wraps the application or specific sections to provide data like quotes, token pairs, and transaction status to child components.
patterns.usage: npm install @orderly.network/ui-transfer
notes: This component does not render any UI itself; it acts as a state container.
Must be an ancestor of any component consuming the swap/deposit context (like `SwapForm` or `SwapIndicator`).
It typically initializes the connection to the Orderly network for transfer operations.

patterns.name: SwapIndicator
patterns.description: A visual component that indicates the direction of a swap between two tokens. It typically renders an arrow or an icon showing the conversion from the source token to the target token.
patterns.usage: npm install @orderly.network/ui-transfer
notes: Useful for placing between 'From' and 'To' input fields in a swap interface.
The `className` prop allows for custom styling of the icon (e.g., rotation, color).
It is a presentational component and does not handle swap logic itself.

patterns.name: WithdrawForm
patterns.description: A comprehensive form component that handles the logic and UI for withdrawing funds from the Orderly network to an external wallet or another chain.
patterns.usage: npm install @orderly.network/ui-transfer
notes: Encapsulates input validation, amount calculation, and transaction submission.
The `onSuccess` callback is triggered after the withdrawal transaction is confirmed.
Often used in conjunction with `WithdrawWarningMessage` to display user alerts.

patterns.name: WithdrawWarningMessage
patterns.description: A conditional alert component that displays specific warnings based on the withdrawal parameters, such as bridgeless transfers, cross-chain fees, or amount limits.
patterns.usage: npm install @orderly.network/ui-transfer
notes: Helps users understand risks or requirements (e.g., 'Cross-chain transfer fees apply').
Props like `checkIsBridgeless` and `crossChainTrans` toggle specific warning messages.
Best placed directly above or below the `WithdrawForm` input fields.
